Description.val:
The Navy Multiband Terminal (NMT) System provides funds for procurement of ship, submarine, and shore protected and wideband Military Satellite Communications (MILSATCOM) terminals via earth orbiting relay satellites in the Super High Frequency, Ka, and Extremely High Frequency (EHF) bands. The NMT provides warfighters with the assured, jam resistant, secure SATCOM for message traffic, data transfer and secure voice communications. These procurements are scheduled to meet the satellite communications requirements established by the Chief of Naval Operations in the Fleet Communications Planning and Programming documents.

NAVY MULTIBAND TERMINAL (NMT - NS108):  The NMT program is the next generation maritime military satellite communications terminal.  The NMT Program is the required Navy component to the Advanced Extremely High Frequency (AEHF) Program for enhancing protected and survivable satellite communications to Naval forces.  NMT multiband communication capabilities will communicate two way Ka-Band on Wideband Global SATCOM (WGS) and shipboard and submarine terminals to communicate with X-Band using the Defense Satellite Communications System and WGS.  NMT is compatible with today's Navy Low Data Rate/Medium Data Rate  terminals, X-Band terminals and will sustain the MILSATCOM architecture by providing connectivity across the spectrum of mission areas, to include land, air and naval warfare, special operations, strategic nuclear operations, strategic defense, theater missile defense, and space operations and intelligence.  The NMT system will replenish and improve on the capabilities of both the Military Strategic and Tactical Relay System (MILSTAR) and WGS system by equipping the warfighters with the assured, jam resistant, secure communications as described in the Operational Requirements Document (Wideband Gapfiller System ORD, AFSPC ORD 004-99, May 3, 2000) for the joint AEHF Satellite Communications and WGS System.

Justification.val: FY15 continues the procurement of full capability terminals and backfits for X/Ka and Advanced EHF Time Division Multiple Access Interface Processor (ATIP) on ship terminals procured in prior years.

Name.@footnote: 1. FY13-15 procurements include X/Ka capability backfits on ship terminals procured in FY10-11.   2. FY14 and beyond procurements include the addition of the Advanced EHF Time Division Multiple Access Interface Processor (ATIP) and its backfits on terminals previously procured in FY10-13.  3. A new competitive production contract is planned for FY15. 4. Unit cost for procurements and installations will vary from year to year due to a different mix of platform variants and quantity of components procured each year as well as additional costs for X/Ka backfits and ATIP capability. In FY15 the NMT program is accelerating the NMT X/Ka backfit procurements originally planned for FY16. The backfit and ATIP procurements account for approximately 26% of the FY15 procurement costs. Additionally, unit cost for procurements is also determined by contract quantity pricing at the total order level (ship/sub/shore).  5.  Unit cost for NMT procurements and installations vary from year to year due to the mix of platform variants (large vs small decks), submarines and shore sites. Large decks consist of 2 Communications Groups with 4, 5, or 6 antennas.  Small decks consist of 1 Communication Group with 2, 3, or 4 antennas. There are 13 variants of the NMT and antenna size varies by class (ranging from 54" to 96"). 6. Procurement lead time is 15 months to deliver the first terminal. Deliveries continue over a 12 month period with the last delivery occurring 27 months after award.  Per contract, a minimum of 2 terminals are delivered each month during the next 12 months to keep the production line open. For FY15 the expected delivery will be from April 2016 to March 2017. 7. Per Fleet Modernization Program (FMP) first quarter installations reflected in the Installation Schedule are funded in the prior year in order to be able to fund the installation contracts 90 days prior to the beginning of shipboard installation work. 90 days are needed to allow sufficient time for the contractor to plan the work schedule, order material, and perform necessary fabrication.   8. The installation plan is supported by a flexible industry labor base. Installation cost fluctuations are attributed to and are dependent on class, configuration of the platform, and configuration of the NMT installed (single CG, dual CGs, Q/Ka, Q/X/Ka, 2-6 antenna configuration, shore, or submarine). For example, the estimated installation cost for a LHD 1 class (large deck) platform with dual Q/X/Ka capability is approximately four times greater than a DDG 51 class platform (small deck) with the same Q/X/Ka capability. Fielded platforms with the Q/Ka configuration require an X/Ka backfit, which has additional costs dependent on platform (large vs small deck). Furthermore, installation costs increase in FY15 as the majority of terminals fielded begin to change from Q/Ka to Q/X/Ka capable.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Method : Installation Name: Navy Multiband Terminal (NMT) - Afloat

Description.val:
[Afloat Ship] Provides jam resistant, low probability of interception and detection for protected extended data rate communications with AEHF capability.																

[Afloat Sub] Provides jam resistant, low probability of interception and detection for protected extended data rate communications with AEHF capability.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Method : Installation Name: Navy Multiband Terminal (NMT) - Ashore

Description.val: [Ashore] Provides jam resistant, low probability of interception and detection for protected extended data rate communications with AEHF capability.
